revision.text:
The '''Melbourne Cabaret Festival''' is a not-for-profit [[cabaret]] [[festival]] that has been held each year since 2010 in the city of [[Melbourne]] in [[Australia]] and that by 2013 had grown to become the world’s second-largest event of its kind.<ref>[http://aussietheatre.com.au/news/melbourne-cabaret-festival-records-massive-growth-in-attendance-2013#.VC3p_RYQZco "Melbourne Cabaret Festival records massive growth in attendance"]. Retrieved on 3 October 2014.</ref>
The festival was launched in 2010 by the former Melbourne nightclub owners Neville Sice and David Read and has been run each year since then by them.<ref>Sally Bennett, “Butterfly Club spreads wings”, ''Herald Sun'', 11 January 2011, http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/arts/butterfly-club-spreads-wings/story-fn7euh6j-1225985226603. Retrieved 6 June 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/stage/still-misbeehiving-a-decade-later-20120711-21w26.html "Still misbeehiving a decade later"]. Retrieved on 3 October 2014.</ref> It was the first Australian festival to use "crowdfunding" as its main source of seed money. <ref>[http://www.theweeklyreview.com.au/well-read/interviews/5267-money-for-something/#.VC3ojRYQZco "Interviews | Money for something"]. Retrieved on 3 October 2014.</ref>
The [[United States|American]] [[singer]] [[Mary Wilson (singer)|Mary Wilson]] of [[The Supremes]] was the headliner artist in 2013 when the festival was reported to have attracted total audiences of more than 15,200.<ref>Erin James, “Melbourne Cabaret Festival records massive growth in attendance”, AussieTheatre.com.au, 9 July 2013, http://aussietheatre.com.au/news/melbourne-cabaret-festival-records-massive-growth-in-attendance-2013#.U5Cs1hwSB9k. Retrieved 6 June 2014.</ref>
The fifth annual Melbourne Cabaret Festival took place between 19 June and 6 July 2014 at various [[nightclub]] venues across the city and was reported to have featured more than 100 performers in 30 separate shows by cabaret and [[burlesque]] artists from Australia and the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>http://www.au.timeout.com/melbourne/clubs/events/11305/melbourne-cabaret-festival-2014. Retrieved 4 June 2014.</ref>
==References==
{{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.melbournecabaret.com Melbourne Cabaret Festival] * https://www.facebook.com/MelbourneCabaret. Retrieved 4 June 2014.
[[Category:Cabaret]] [[Category:Festivals in Melbourne]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2010]] [[Category:Performing arts in Melbourne]]

{{More citations needed|date=December 2014}} {{Expand Greek|Μελίνα Μερκούρη|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Melina Mercouri | image = Melina Mercouri.JPG | caption = Mercouri in 1982 | native_name = Μελίνα Μερκούρη | birth_name = Maria Amalia Mercouri | birth_place = [[Athens]], Greece | birth_date = {{birth date|1920|10|18|df=y}} | death_date = {{death date and age|1994|03|06|1920|12|18|df=y}} | death_place = [[Upper East Side]], [[New York City]], U.S. | resting_place = [[First Cemetery of Athens]] | education = [[National Theatre of Greece Drama School]] | occupation = {{flatlist| *[[Actor|Actress]] *[[Singing|Singer]] *[[Politician]]}} | years_active = 1945–1994 | spouse = {{marriage|Panos Harokopos|1941|1962|end=divorced}}
{{marriage|[[Jules Dassin]]|1966|1994|end=her death}} | parents = [[Stamatis Mercouris]]
Irene Lappa }} '''Maria Amalia''' "'''Melina'''" '''Mercouri''' (18 October 1920 – 6 March 1994) was a [[Greeks|Greek]] actress, singer, and politician. She received an [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Oscar]] nomination and won a [[Cannes Film Festival Award for Best Actress|Cannes Film Festival Award]] for her performance in the 1960 film ''[[Never on Sunday]]''. Mercouri was also nominated for three [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globes]] and two [[British Academy Film Awards|BAFTA Awards]] in her acting career. As a politician, she was a member of the [[PASOK]] and the [[Hellenic Parliament]]. In October 1981, Mercouri became the first female [[Ministry of Culture and Sports (Greece)|Minister of Culture and Sports]]. ==Early life== Mercouri was born in 1920 to a former [[cavalry officer]] and member of the Greek parliament, [[Stamatis Mercouris]], and his wife, Eirini Lappa. When she completed her secondary education, she attended the National Theatre's Drama School, graduating in 1944. Mercouri's first husband was a wealthy landowner, Panos Harokopos; the couple divorced in 1962. As an actress, Mercouri made her film debut in ''[[Stella (1955 film)|Stella]]'' (1955) and met international success with her performances in ''[[Never on Sunday]]'' (1960, with future husband [[Jules Dassin]]), ''[[Phaedra (film)|Phaedra]]'', ''[[Topkapi (film)|Topkapi]]'', and ''[[Promise at Dawn]]''. She won the award for [[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Actress]] at the [[1960 Cannes Film Festival]]. She was nominated for an [[Academy Award]], a [[Tony Award]], three [[Golden Globe Awards]], and two [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA Awards]]. A political [[Activism|activist]] during the [[Greek military junta of 1967–1974]], Mercouri became a member of the [[Hellenic Parliament]] in 1977 and became the first female [[Minister for Culture (Greece)|Minister for Culture of Greece]] in 1981. In 1983, Mercouri proposed the programme of the [[European Capital of Culture]], which was established by the [[European Union]] in 1985. Mercouri was a strong advocate for the return to [[Athens]] of the [[Parthenon Marbles]], which were removed from the [[Parthenon]], and are now displayed in the [[British Museum]] in [[London]].{{cite web|last=Casey |first=Christopher |date=October 30, 2008 |title="Grecian Grandeurs and the Rude Wasting of Old Time": Britain, the Elgin Marbles, and Post-Revolutionary Hellenism |work=Foundations. Volume III, Number 1 |url=http://ww2.jhu.edu/foundations/?p=8 |accessdate=2009-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513053304/http://ww2.jhu.edu/foundations/?p=8 |archivedate=May 13, 2009 |df= }} ==Acting career== ===Early years on stage=== After her graduation, Mercouri joined the [[National Theatre of Greece]] and played the role of [[Electra]] in [[Eugene O'Neill]]'s play ''[[Mourning Becomes Electra]]'' in 1945. In 1949, she had her first major success in the theatre playing [[Blanche DuBois]] in ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]]'', written by [[Tennessee Williams]] and staged by [[Karolos Koun]]'s Art Theatre. Until 1950, she also worked in the same theatre in other plays by [[Aldous Huxley]], [[Arthur Miller]] and [[André Roussin]]. Mercouri then moved to [[Paris]], where she appeared in boulevard plays by [[Jacques Deval]] and [[Marcel Achard]], and met famous [[France|French]] [[playwright]]s and [[novelist]]s such as [[Jean Cocteau]], [[Jean-Paul Sartre]], [[Colette]] and [[Françoise Sagan]]. In 1953, Mercouri received the [[Marika Kotopouli]] Prize. Mercouri returned to Greece in 1955. At the Kotopouli-Rex Theatre, Mercouri starred in ''[[Macbeth]]'' by [[William Shakespeare]] and ''[[L'Alouette (The Lark)|L'Alouette]]'' by [[Jean Anouilh]]. {{citation needed|date=December 2009}} ===International success=== [[File:Μελίνα Μερκούρη.jpg|thumb|Melina Mercouri in ''[[Phaedra (film)|Phaedra]]'', 1962]] Mercouri's first movie was the [[Greek language]] film ''[[Stella (1955 film)|Stella]]'' (1955), directed by ''[[Zorba the Greek]]'' director [[Michael Cacoyannis]]. The film received special praise at the [[1956 Cannes Film Festival]], where she met [[United States|American]] [[film director]] [[Jules Dassin]], with whom she would share not only her career but also her life. Their first professional pairing was 1957's ''[[He Who Must Die]]''. Other films by Dassin and featuring Mercouri followed, such as ''[[The Law (1959 film)|The Law]]'' (1959). Mercouri became well-known to international audiences when she starred in ''[[Never on Sunday]]'' (1960), in which Dassin was the director and co-star. For this film, she earned the [[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Actress Award]] at the [[1960 Cannes Film Festival]] and was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] and the [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role]].[http://www.bafta.org Profile], bafta.org; accessed 6 December 2014. After her first major international success, Mercouri went on to star in ''[[Phaedra (film)|Phaedra]]'' (1962), for which she was nominated again for the [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA Award]] and the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama|Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in Motion Picture Drama]]. The recognition of her acting talent did not stop though, as her role in ''[[Topkapi (film)|Topkapi]]'' (1964) granted her one more nomination, this time for the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]]. Mercouri worked with such directors as [[Joseph Losey]], [[Vittorio De Sica]], [[Ronald Neame]], [[Carl Foreman]], [[Norman Jewison]], and starred in films like [[Spanish language]] ''[[The Uninhibited]]'' by [[Juan Antonio Bardem]]. Mercouri continued her stage career in the Greek production of [[Tennessee Williams]]'s ''[[Sweet Bird of Youth]]'' (1960), under the direction of [[Karolos Koun]]. In 1967, she played the leading role in ''[[Illya Darling]]'' (from 11 April 1967 to 13 January 1968) on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]],{{iBDB name|52785}} for which she was nominated for the [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Musical]]. Mercouri's performance in ''[[Promise at Dawn]]'' (1970) earned her another [[Golden Globe Award]] nomination. On 8 October 1962,[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2FteAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AmENAAAAIBAJ&pg=2957,4135065&dq=host-john-daly-seated-the-actress&hl=en ''What's My Line'' incident of 8 October 1962]; accessed 6 December 2014. Mercouri appeared on the American TV show ''[[What's My Line]]''. After the panel were blindfolded, a strange man appeared on-stage and proclaimed himself "the second mystery guest". Host [[John Charles Daly]] quickly called for "the relieving unit" and said "schedule two" (a coded phrase used on live broadcasts in case of an emergency: the cameras are turned to a neutral position and the sound is cut off). The man talked a bit about a dating service he apparently owned before being hustled off the stage by announcer [[Johnny Olson]] and [[executive producer]] [[Gil Fates]]. Daly apologized to the panel and the program continued.{{YouTube|YW8qFj1G5j0}} Mercouri concentrated on her stage career for the following years, playing in the Greek productions of ''[[The Threepenny Opera]]'' and, for a second time, ''Sweet Bird of Youth'', in addition to the [[Theatre of ancient Greece|ancient Greek]] [[Tragedy|tragedies]] ''[[Medea (play)|Medea]]'' and ''[[Oresteia]]''. She retired from film acting in 1978, when she played in her last film, ''[[A Dream of Passion]]'', directed by her husband, [[Jules Dassin]]. Mercouri's last performance on stage was in the opera ''Pylades'' at the [[Athens Concert Hall]] in 1992, portraying [[Clytemnestra]]. ===Filmography=== {|class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%;" border="2" cellpadding="4" background: #f9f9f9; |- align="center" ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Year ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Film ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Role ! style="background:#B0C4DE;" | Notes |- | 1955 | ''[[Stella (1955 film)|Stella]]'' | Stella |Nominated - [[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Cannes Film Festival Best Actress Award]] |- | 1957 | ''[[He Who Must Die]]'' | Katerina | |- | 1958 | ''[[The Gypsy and the Gentleman]]'' | Belle | |- | 1959 | ''[[The Law (1959 film)|The Law]]'' | Donna Lucrezia | |- | 1960 | ''[[Never on Sunday]]'' | Ilya |Won - [[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Cannes Film Festival Best Actress Award]]
Won - [[NYFCC Award for Best Actress]]
Nominated - [[Academy Award for Best Actress]]
Nominated - [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role|BAFTA Award for Best Foreign Actress]] |- | rowspan=2|1961 | ''[[The Last Judgment (1961 film)|The Last Judgment]]'' | Foreign lady | |- | ''Long Live Henry IV... Long Live Love'' | Marie de Médicis | |- | 1962 | ''[[Phaedra (film)|Phaedra]]'' | Phaedra |Nominated - [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role|BAFTA Award for Best Foreign Actress]]
Nominated - [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama]] |- | 1963 | ''[[The Victors (film)|The Victors]]'' | Magda | |- | 1964 | ''[[Topkapi (film)|Topkapi]]'' | Elizabeth Lipp |Nominated - [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]] |- Won - [[David di Donatello Awards]] |- | 1965 | ''[[The Uninhibited]]'' | Jenny | |- | rowspan=2|1966 | ''[[A Man Could Get Killed]]'' | Aurora | |- | ''[[10:30 P.M. Summer]]'' | Maria | |- | 1969 | ''[[Gaily, Gaily]]'' | Lil | |- | 1970 | ''[[Promise at Dawn]]'' | Nina Kacew |Nominated - [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama]] |- | 1974 | ''[[The Rehearsal (1974 film)|The Rehearsal]]'' | Belle | |- | 1975 | ''[[Once Is Not Enough]]'' | Karla | |- | 1975 | ''Kipros'' | Herself | |- | 1977 | ''Nasty Habits'' | Sister Gertrude | |- | 1978 | ''[[A Dream of Passion]]'' | Maya | |- | 1981 | ''Gynaikes stin exoria'' | Narrator | (final role) |} ==As singer== {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2014}} One of her first songs was by [[Manos Hadjidakis]] and [[Nikos Gatsos]]. It was titled ''Hartino to Fengaraki'' ("Papermoon") and was a part of the Greek production of ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]]'' in 1949, in which she starred as [[Blanche DuBois]]. The first official recording of this, now-legendary song was made by [[Nana Mouskouri]] in 1960, although the company Sirius, created by [[Manos Hadjidakis]], issued, in 2004, a recording Melina had made for [[France|French]] television during the 1960s. Her recordings of "Athenes, ma Ville", a collaboration with [[Vangelis]], and "Melinaki", were popular in France. Her recording of "Feggari mou, Agapi mou" (Phaedra) was quite popular and was later covered by [[Marinella]] in 1965. ==Political career== ===Activism against the Greek junta=== At the time of the [[coup d'état]] in [[Greece]] by a group of colonels of the [[Military of Greece|Greek military]] on 21 April 1967, she was in the [[United States]], playing in ''[[Illya Darling]]''. She immediately joined the struggle against the [[Greek military junta of 1967–1974|Greek Military Junta]] and started an international campaign, travelling all over the world to inform the public and contribute to the isolation and fall of the colonels. As a result, the dictatorial regime revoked her [[Greek nationality law|Greek citizenship]] and confiscated her property.{{cite book|title=Newsweek|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XRHkAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=17 March 2013|year=1967|publisher=Newsweek|quote=Greek word for honey (rneli), but there was acid in her throaty voice last week as vibrant Melina Mercouri condemned Brig. Gen. Stylianos Pattakos, strong man of the Greek revolutionary junta which had just stripped her of citizenship and property ... Mr. Pattakos was born a Fascist; he will die a Fascist", said the passionate performer who until the recent coup did as ...}} When her citizenship was taken away, she said: ''"I was born a [[Greeks|Greek]] and I will die a Greek. [[Stylianos Pattakos|Mr. Pattakos]] (the then [[Minister of the Interior]] of the junta who made these decisions against her) was born a fascist and he will die a fascist"''.{{cite book|title=Newsweek|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wMgmAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=17 March 2013|year=1967|publisher=Newsweek, Incorporated|quote="I was born a Greek; I will die a Creek. Mr. Pattakos was born a Fascist; he will die a Fascist", said the passionate performer who until the recent coup did as much to spur Creek tourism as all the ancient ruins combined. ...}}{{cite book|title=Books and Bookmen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7RJVAAAAYAAJ|accessdate=17 March 2013|year=1971|publisher=Hansom Books|quote=When asked if she had any comment on this she replied: 'I was born Greek. I shall die Greek. Mr Pattakos was born a fascist. He will die a fascist.}}{{cite book|title=Labor Today|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lTe9AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=17 March 2013|year=|publisher=National Center for Trade Union Action and Democracy|quote=No wonder the talented actress Melina Mercouri, after being stripped of her Greek citizenship in absentia, said of junta member Colonel Pattakos : "I was born a Greek and I will die a Greek. Pattakos was born a Fascist and will die a Fascist.}}{{cite book|author=Helen Vlachos|title=Free Greek voices: a political anthology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lp4JAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=17 March 2013|year=1971|publisher=(10 Gayfere St., SWIP 3HN), Doric Publications Ltd.|quote=He repeated it. And my answer came like water from a fountain: 'I was born a Greek, I will die a Greek; Pattakos was born Fascist, he will die Fascist . . .' "And now what will happen, Melina?" I am asked. Now there will be a trial at some ...}}{{cite book|title=Balkania|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sGIMAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=17 March 2013|year=1967|publisher=Balkania Publishing Company|quote=... Patakos was born a fascist and will die a fascist," Miss Mercouri said at a press conference she called shortly after hearing that her citizenship had been ...}} While in London she worked with [[Amalia Fleming]] and [[Helen Vlachos]] of [[Kathimerini]] against the junta of the colonels.{{cite web|author=RICHARD CLOGG|title=Obituary: Helen Vlachos|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-helen-vlachos-1578044.html|publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|date=17 October 1995|accessdate=15 March 2013}} ===Involvement in politics=== {{unreferenced section|date=December 2014}} After the fall of the Junta and during the ''[[metapolitefsi]]'' in 1974, Mercouri settled in Greece and was one of the founding members of the [[Panhellenic Socialist Movement]] (PASOK), a [[centre-left]] [[political party]]. She was a member of the party's Central Committee and a rapporteur for the Culture Section, while being involved in the women's movement as well. In the [[Greek legislative election, 1974|Greek legislative elections of 1974]], she was a PASOK candidate in the [[Piraeus Prefecture|Piraeus B]] [[List of parliamentary constituencies of Greece|constituency]], but the 7,500 votes were not enough to secure a seat for her in the [[Hellenic Parliament]] (she needed 33 more votes), something that came true in the [[Greek legislative election, 1977|elections of 1977]], in which she obtained the highest number of votes in the whole of Greece. {{citation needed|date=December 2009}} ===Minister for Culture: 1981–1989=== {{One source|section|date=December 2014}} [[File:Melina Mercouri (1985).jpg|thumb|Melina Mercouri (1985)]] When PASOK won the elections of 1981, Mercouri was appointed [[Minister for Culture (Greece)|Minister for Culture of Greece]], being the first female in that post. She would serve in that position for two terms until 1989, when PASOK lost the elections and [[New Democracy (Greece)|New Democracy]] formed a cabinet. As Minister for Culture, Mercouri took advantage of her fame abroad and got in contact with great European leaders in order to promote Greece. She strongly advocated the return to [[Athens]] of the [[Elgin Marbles|Parthenon Marbles]], that were removed from [[Parthenon]] and other buildings on the [[Acropolis of Athens]] by [[Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin]], and are now part of the [[British Museum]] collection in [[London]]. In anticipation of the return of the marbles, she held an international competition for the construction of the [[New Acropolis Museum]], designated to display them and finally established in 2008. One of her greatest achievements was the establishment of the institution of the [[European Capital of Culture]] within the framework of cultural policy of the [[European Union]], that she had conceived and proposed in 1983, with Athens inaugurating this institution being the first title-holder in 1985, while she was a devoted supporter of the [[1996 Summer Olympics bids|Athens bid]] to host the [[1996 Summer Olympics|Centennial Olympic Games]]. In 1983, during the first Greek [[presidency of the Council of the European Union]], Mercouri invited the Ministers for Culture of the other nine [[Member State of the European Union|member states of the European Union]] at [[Zappeion]], in order to increase the people's cultural awareness, since there was not any reference to cultural questions in the [[Treaties of Rome|Treaty of Rome]], which led to the establishment of formal sessions between the Ministers of Culture of the European Union. During the second presidency of Greece in 1988, she supported the cooperation between [[Eastern Europe]] and the European Union, which was finally implemented one year later with the celebration of the Month of Culture in Eastern countries. {{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} Mercouri commissioned a study for the integration of all the archaeological sites of Athens to create a traffic-free archaeological park to promote the [[Culture of Greece|Greek culture]]. She introduced free access to museums and archaeological sites for Greek citizens, organized a series of exhibitions of Greek cultural heritage and [[modern Greek art]] worldwide, supported the restoration of buildings of special architectural interest and the completion of the [[Athens Concert Hall]], backed the project of the [[Museum of Byzantine culture]] in [[Thessaloniki]] and established annual literary pizes. {{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} In June 1986 Melina Mercouri spoke at the Oxford Union, a world-famous debating society, on the matter of the Parthenon Marbles and whether they should remain in London or be returned to Greece. She argued passionately for the Marble's reunification. As she explains, the Marbles are more to Greece than just works of art: they are an essential element of Greek heritage, which ties directly into cultural identity. She said: "You must understand what the Parthenon Marbles mean to us. They are our pride. They are our sacrifices. They are our noblest symbol of excellence. They are a tribute to the democratic philosophy. They are our aspirations and our name. They are the essence of Greekness."Mercouri, Melina. “Melina's Speech to the Oxford Union.” The Parthenon Marbles, Ian Swindale, 9 Feb. 1997, www.parthenon.newmentor.net/speech.htm Her stance on the matter has inspired a new wave of activism on the issue, and inspired pride in Greek culture and history. ===Minister for Culture: 1993–1994=== {{One source|section|date=December 2014}} In the [[Greek legislative election, November 1989|legislative elections of November 1989]], PASOK lost and Mercouri was elected a member of the Hellenic Parliament and remained a member of the party's Executive Bureau. In 1990, she was a candidate for [[List of mayors of Athens|Mayor of Athens]] but she was defeated by [[Antonis Tritsis]]. After PASOK's win in the [[Greek legislative election, 1993|election of 1993]], she was back at the Ministry for Culture.[http://www.yppo.gr/1/e1120.jsp?person=6 Melina Mercouri profile], Hellenic Ministry of Culture website; accessed 6 December 2014. Her major goals in this second term in office were: to create a cultural park in the [[Aegean Sea]] in order to protect and enhance the environment and civilization of the [[Aegean Islands]], and to link culture with education at all [[Education in Greece|education levels]], introducing a system of post-training of teachers. ==Death== Mercouri died on 6 March 1994 at [[Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center]], [[New York City]], from [[lung cancer]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1994/03/07/obituaries/melina-mercouri-actress-and-politician-is-dead.html Melina Mercouri, Actress and Politician, Is Dead] She was survived by her husband, [[Jules Dassin]]. She had no children. She received a [[state funeral]] with [[Prime Minister of Greece|Prime Minister]]'s honors at the [[First Cemetery of Athens]] four days later. '''The Melina Mercouri Foundation''' was founded by her widower. After her death, UNESCO established the ‘Melina Mercouri International Prize for the Safeguarding and Management of Cultural Landscapes (UNESCO-Greece)' which rewards outstanding examples of action to safeguard and enhance the world's major cultural landscapes.[http://www.melinamercourifoundation.org.gr Foundation Melina Mercouri] {{el icon}} {{en icon}} ==Gallery== File:Athens Metro Acropolis station.jpg|[[Athens Metro]] Acropolis station. Melina's photograph on the right. File:GR Ateny, popiersie, Melina Merkuri, fot I Nowicka.JPG|Bust of Melina Mercouri, Athens ==References== {{Reflist}} 17. [http://www.ocnal.com/2018/09/melina-mercouri-greek-minister-of.html Melina Mercouri, the Greek Minister of Albanian descent that revolutionized the European Culture] ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0580479|name=Melina Mercouri}} *{{IBDB name}} *[http://www.melinamercourifoundation.org.gr/ Foundation Melina Mercouri] {{el icon}} {{en icon}} *[https://movies.nytimes.com/person/1015117/Melina-Mercouri Melina Mercouri] at ''[[The New York Times]] Movies'' {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=Andreas Andrianopoulos}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Minister for Culture (Greece)|Minister for Culture of Greece]]|years=1981–1989}} {{s-aft|after=[[Georgios Mylonas]]}} {{s-bef|before=[[Dora Bakoyannis]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Minister for Culture (Greece)|Minister for Culture of Greece]]|years=1993–1994}} {{s-aft|after=[[Thanos Mikroutsikos]]}} {{s-end}} {{Prix d'interprétation féminine 1960–1979}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mercouri, Melina}} [[Category:Greek film actresses]] [[Category:Greek stage actresses]] [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:1994 deaths]] [[Category:Culture ministers of Greece]] [[Category:Greek actor-politicians]] [[Category:Greek female singers]] [[Category:Actresses from Athens]] [[Category:Singers from Athens]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New York (state)]] [[Category:Deaths from lung cancer]] [[Category:Greek socialists]] [[Category:Greek democracy activists]] [[Category:PASOK politicians]] [[Category:Greek MPs 1977–81]] [[Category:Greek MPs 1981–85]] [[Category:Greek MPs 1985–89]] [[Category:Greek MPs 1989 (June–November)]] [[Category:Greek MPs 1989–90]] [[Category:Greek MPs 1990–93]] [[Category:Greek MPs 1993–96]] [[Category:Greek women in politics]] [[Category:Women government ministers of Greece]] [[Category:Burials at the First Cemetery of Athens]] [[Category:Cinema of Greece]] [[Category:20th-century Greek actresses]] [[Category:20th-century Greek singers]] [[Category:20th-century women politicians]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]]

{{About|the 2017 video game|the 2012 horror film|A Night in the Woods}} {{redirect|Gregg Lee|other people|Greg Lee (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox video game | title = Night in the Woods | image = Night in the Woods.jpg | caption = Digital storefront artwork, featuring the game's iconography and cast of characters | developer = {{Plainlist| * Infinite Fall * [[Secret Lab]] * 22nd Century Toys }} | publisher = [[Finji]] | designer = {{Plainlist| * [[Alec Holowka]] * Scott Benson * Bethany Hockenberry }} | programmer = {{Plainlist| * Alec Holowka * Jon Manning * Paris Buttfield-Addison }} | artist = {{Plainlist| * Scott Benson * Charles Huettner }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * Bethany Hockenberry * Scott Benson }} | composer = {{Plainlist| * Alec Holowka * Scott Benson }} | engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] | platforms = {{Hlist|[[Microsoft Windows]]|[[macOS]]|[[Linux]]|[[PlayStation 4]]|[[Xbox One]]|[[Nintendo Switch]]|[[iOS]]|[[Android (OS)|Android]]}} | released = {{Collapsible list|title=February 21, 2017|titlestyle=font-weight:normal;font-size:12px;background:transparent;text-align:left|'''Microsoft Windows''', '''macOS''', '''Linux''', '''PlayStation 4'''
{{Video game release|NA|February 21, 2017|EU|February 28, 2017}}'''Xbox One'''
{{Video game release|WW|December 13, 2017}}'''Nintendo Switch'''
{{Video game release|WW|February 1, 2018}}'''iOS''', '''Android'''
{{Video game release|WW|2018}}}} | genre = [[Adventure game|Adventure]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }} '''''Night in the Woods''''' (abbreviated as '''NITW''') is a [[Single-player video game|single-player]] [[adventure game]] released for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[macOS]], [[Linux]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]], and [[ Nintendo Switch]]. The game released for Microsoft Windows, macOS, Linux, and PlayStation 4 on February 21, 2017. A Version for Xbox One was released on December 13, 2017, while a version for the Nintendo Switch was released on February 1, 2018.{{Cite web |url=http://twinfinite.net/2018/01/night-in-the-woods-is-coming-to-switch-this-week/ |title=Night in the Woods Is Coming to Switch This Week |website=twinfinite.net |language=en-US |access-date=2018-01-16}} Versions for [[iOS]] and [[Android (OS)|Android]] will arrive in 2018. ''Night in the Woods'' is developed by Infinite Fall, a studio founded by [[Video game developer|game designer]] [[Alec Holowka]], and [[animator]]/[[Game art design|illustrator]] Scott Benson. [[Secret Lab]], an Australian studio, built the game's narrative engine, and are creating the mobile version of the game using their sprite compression systems.{{Cite news|url=https://www.secretlab.com.au/blog/2017/11/14/how-night-in-the-woods-uses-yarn-spinner|title=How Night in the Woods Uses Yarn Spinner|work=Secret Lab|access-date=2018-03-23|language=en-AU}} {{Cite news|url=https://www.secretlab.com.au/blog/2017/10/24/small-towns-small-screens-night-in-the-woods-is-coming-to-mobile|title=Small Towns, Small Screens: Night in the Woods is coming to mobile|work=Secret Lab|access-date=2018-03-23|language=en-AU}} It is a story-focused [[exploration game]] in which [[Player (game)|players]] control a young woman named Mae, who recently dropped out of college and has returned to her hometown to find unexpected changes. The game was funded via the [[Crowdfunding in video games|crowdfunding]] platform [[Kickstarter]], where it eventually earned over 400% of its {{US$|50,000|link=yes}} funding goal.{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1307515311/night-in-the-woods/|title=Kickstarter, Night in the Woods project page|publisher=Kickstarter|date = November 22, 2013|accessdate = February 25, 2015}} A companion game titled ''Longest Night'' was released in December 2013 by Holowka and Benson, along with co-[[Video game writer|writer]] Bethany Hockenberry.{{cite web|url=https://finji.itch.io/longest-night|title=Longest Night|work=[[itch.io]]|date=December 21, 2013|accessdate=February 21, 2017}} In December 2014, a second supplemental game was released, titled ''Lost Constellation''.{{cite web | url = https://finji.itch.io/lost-constellation | title = Lost Constellation | date = December 31, 2014 | accessdate = February 25, 2015 | work = [[itch.io]]}} An extended version of the game, titled the ''Weird Autumn'' edition, was released for PC, macOS, Linux, PlayStation 4 and Xbox One on December 13, 2017 and for Nintendo Switch on February 1, 2018. It features new content not seen in the original game, as well as the supplemental games. ''Night in the Woods'' received notable critical praise, mostly for its story, dialogue and characters. ==Overview== Mae, an only child, has returned home to Possum Springs—a town populated by [[Zoomorphism|zoomorphic]] humans.{{Cite web|url=https://curiouscat.me/bombsfall/post/127359166|title=Developer Scott Benson on Characters' Identity|last=Benson|first=Scott|date=March 30, 2017|website=curiouscat.me|access-date=2018-02-17}} Now living in her parents' attic, she discovers how much times have changed since the closing of the town's coal mines, uncovering a dark mystery that leads her into the nearby woods. She is forced to confront a horrible secret the town has hidden for decades involving not only the town's mine, but also the recent disappearance of her longtime friend Casey. Mae's friends also include Bea, a cigarette-smoking alligator and Mae's childhood friend; Gregg, a hyperactive fox; and his boyfriend, a bear named Angus. ''[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]'' describes the themes covered as "mental illness, depression, the stagnancy of the middle and lower classes, and the slow death of small town America."{{cite web|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2015/06/the-10-best-videogames-we-played-at-e3-2015.html|title=The 10 Best Videogames We Played at E3 2015|last2=Irwin|first2=Jon|date=June 22, 2015|last1=Martin|first1=Garrett|work=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|accessdate=March 7, 2017}} As Mae, players run, jump, and learn other [[Game mechanics|mechanics]] that allow them to explore Possum Springs. Benson describes the key actions for the player as "explore, converse, see and touch", while Holowka describes their approach as "narrative-focused" rather than "[[gameplay]]-first".{{cite web|url=http://killscreendaily.com/articles/charming-melancholy-night-woods-picks-where-gone-home-left/|title=The charming, melancholy Night in the Woods picks up where Gone Home left off|last=Cox|first=Davis|date=May 1, 2014|work=[[Kill Screen]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908221108/http://killscreendaily.com/articles/charming-melancholy-night-woods-picks-where-gone-home-left/|archivedate=September 8, 2015|deadurl=yes|accessdate=September 5, 2015|df=}} Players make [[Interactive storytelling|decisions]] that affect the course of the story, though Benson has said, "it's more like 'do you hang out with this person?' Okay, cool. That person might not know you as well by the end of the game, but this person you hung out with, you're going to get to see their storyline."{{cite web | last=Matulef|first=Jeffrey|url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-06-22-games-they-are-achangin-a-look-at-nostalgic-adventure-night-in-the-woods | title = Night in the Woods is like Gone Home, in third-person, with talking animals | work = [[Eurogamer]]|date= June 25, 2014 | accessdate = February 25, 2015}} ==Plot== Margaret "Mae" Borowski is a 20-year-old college dropout, who relocates back to her hometown of Possum Springs, which has been struck by the closure of the coal mines and the [[Economic stagnation|stagnating economy]]. She meets up with her old friends, including gloomy but intelligent Beatrice "Bea" Santello, hyperactive [[anarchist]] troublemaker Greggory "Gregg" Lee, and Gregg's quiet, modest boyfriend Angus Delaney. Mae also learns that another one of her old friends, Casey Hartley, has mysteriously disappeared. Mae spends several days exploring Possum Springs and spending time with her friends, but she also begins to have strange and vivid dreams. At the town's [[Halloween]] festival, Mae witnesses a teenager being kidnapped by a mysterious figure. The four friends begin working together to figure out what is going on, with Mae's [[mental health]] slowly deteriorating with every one of her dreams. After intensive searching, the four stumble across a strange group of cloaked figures in the woods, who chase after them; Mae ends up falling and lapses into a coma. Mae eventually wakes up and returns to her friends, and she reveals that the reason she dropped out was due to her increasing dissociation from people and the world (it is implied that Mae suffers from some sort of [[dissociative disorder]]), seeing everything as merely shapes. Mae's journal, in which she draws pictures for each major event in the game, was given to her by a doctor to write down her emotions after she bludgeoned a student with a softball bat six years ago as a result of a dissociative episode. Due to this incident, the townsfolk became wary of Mae and caused a financial and emotional strain in her family. As her dissociation worsened at college, Mae mustered up the strength to leave and return home, hoping that being back in Possum Springs would help her return to normal. Still wounded, Mae decides to venture out into the woods alone to find the group who chased her and the others, only for Gregg, Bea, and Angus to refuse to let her go by herself. The group enter the old mines and meet the mysterious group, who are revealed to be a [[cult]]. The cult turns out to be behind the kidnappings of several residents, including Casey, taking those whom they deem useless to society and whom they say will "not be missed" into the mines to [[sacrifice]] them to a god-like [[chthonic]] entity called the Black Goat in exchange for keeping the economy of Possum Springs afloat. The cult's leader allows the group to leave, threatening them never to tell anyone about the cult - however while riding up the mine's elevator, a member of the group attempts to kill Mae. The others manage to save her and the elevator falls, collapsing the mine and presumably trapping the cult underground. Depending on who the player interacted with the most throughout the course of the game, Mae will sit down with either Bea or Gregg and talk about the events of the previous night, and all the things that have happened in Possum Springs. The others join them shortly after, and Mae tells them that although they will all be forced to grow and adapt to life as it goes on for better and for worse, they can still enjoy their time together now. The game ends as the four decide to forget about their problems for the time being and have band practice. ==Development== ''Night in the Woods'' was announced on October 22, 2013, on Kickstarter. Holowka and Benson set a {{US$|50,000}} funding goal, which was reached in only 26 hours.{{cite web|url=https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1307515311/night-in-the-woods/posts/639908|title=FULLY FUNDED! Also, stretch goals? Consoles? Linux? |publisher=Kickstarter|date = October 24, 2013|accessdate = February 25, 2015}} The project eventually earned over {{US$|200,000}} in crowdfunding. The additional funding allowed Infinite Fall to hire animator Charles Huettner to create additional animations, and for Infinite Ammo and game developer [[Adam Saltsman]] to create a [[roguelike]] that is playable within ''Night in the Woods''. While Benson believed adding further stretch goals would result in additional backers, Infinite Fall limited the amount of stretch goals to avoid [[scope creep]].{{cite web|last=Kuchera|first=Ben|authorlink=Ben Kuchera| url=http://www.penny-arcade.com/report/article/the-goals-that-refused-to-stretch-why-night-in-the-woods-said-no-to-kicksta| title=The goals that refused to stretch: Why Night in the Woods said no to Kickstarter tradition| work=[[The Penny Arcade Report]]| date=November 12, 2013| accessdate=September 5, 2015| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131211184102/http://penny-arcade.com/report/article/the-goals-that-refused-to-stretch-why-night-in-the-woods-said-no-to-kicksta| archivedate=December 11, 2013| deadurl=yes}} Benson names [[Chris Ware]], [[Mike Mignola]], [[Mary Blair]], [[Flannery O’Connor]], and [[Richard Scarry]] as influences on his work on ''Night in the Woods''.{{cite web|last=Ligman|first=Kris|url=http://gamasutra.com/view/news/205993/QA_How_Night_in_the_Woods_taps_into_a_real_sense_of_community.php| title=Q&A: How Night in the Woods taps into a real sense of community| work=[[Gamasutra]]| date=December 2, 2013| accessdate=September 5, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Ewert-Krocker|first=Nate|url=http://www.zam.com/article/1370/rust-belt-gothic-lead-writer-scott-benson-unpacks-the-art-that-inspired-night-in-the-woods| title='Rust Belt Gothic': lead writer Scott Benson unpacks the art that inspired Night in the Woods| work=[[ZAM Network]]| date=March 9, 2017| accessdate=March 11, 2017}} In October 2017, it was announced that the game would be ported to mobile devices by [[Secret Lab]], with a tentative release set for 2018.{{Cite news|last=Fingas|first=Jon|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/10/23/night-in-the-woods-mobile-in-2018/|title=Relentlessly witty 'Night in the Woods' comes to your phone in 2018|work=Engadget|access-date=2017-10-27|language=en-US}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2017/10/23/night-in-the-woods-mobile-version-announced |title=Night in the Woods Mobile Version Announced |last=Gilyadov |first=Alex |date=2017-10-23 |website=IGN |language=en-US |access-date=2017-10-27}} In January 2018, the game was officially announced for the [[Nintendo Switch]], and was released for the console the following month, including all content from the ''Weird Autumn'' edition.{{cite news |last1=Reseigh-Lincoln |first1=Dom |title=The Anthropomorphic Mystery Of Night In The Woods Arrives On Switch This Feb |url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2018/01/the_anthropomorphic_mystery_of_night_in_the_woods_arrives_on_switch_this_feb |accessdate=February 4, 2018 |work=[[Nintendo Life]] |date=January 16, 2018}} ===Soundtrack=== Developer Alec Holowka created the [[Soundtrack#Video game soundtracks|soundtrack]] for ''Night in the Woods''. Three albums of the [[Video game music|game's music]] were released via [[Bandcamp]] on March 9, 2017.{{cite web | url = https://infiniteammo.bandcamp.com/album/night-in-the-woods-vol-1-at-the-end-of-everything | title = Night in the Woods Vol. 1: At The End Of Everything | work = [[Bandcamp]] | accessdate = March 11, 2017}} Holowka names [[DIIV]] as a large influence on the game's score. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | title = | subtitle = | state = | align = | MC = NS: 87
PC: 88
PS4: 87
XONE: 74 | IGN = 8.7/10 {{cite web|title=Night In The Woods Review|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/2017/02/25/night-in-the-woods-review|website=IGN}} | Poly = 7.5/10 {{cite web|title=Night in the Woods review|url=https://www.polygon.com/2017/3/3/14807446/night-in-the-woods-review|website=Polygon}} | GSpot = 9/10 {{cite web|title=Night In The Woods review|url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/night-in-the-woods-review/1900-6416625/|website=GameSpot}} | GI = 8.8/10 {{cite web|title=GameInformer|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/themes/blogs/generic/post.aspx?WeblogApp=playstation4&y=2017&m=02&d=23&WeblogPostName=night-in-the-woods-game-informer-review&GroupKeys=games/night_in_the_woods/|website=Game Informer|access-date=2018-11-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118185523/http://www.gameinformer.com/themes/blogs/generic/post.aspx?WeblogApp=playstation4&y=2017&m=02&d=23&WeblogPostName=night-in-the-woods-game-informer-review&GroupKeys=games%2Fnight_in_the_woods%2F#|archive-date=2018-01-18|dead-url=yes|df=}} | PCGUS = 8.2/10 {{cite web|title=Night in the Woods review|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/night-in-the-woods-review/|website=PC Gamer}} | agg1 = | agg1Score = | agg2 = | agg2Score = | rev1 = | rev1Score = | rev2 = | rev2Score = | award1Pub = | award1 = | award2Pub = | award2 = }} ''Night in the Woods'' received very favourable reviews. On [[Metacritic]], the PS4 version has an average score of 87 from 15 critics{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-4/night-in-the-woods | title = Night in the Woods for PlayStation 4 Reviews - Metacritic | work = [[Metacritic]] | accessdate = March 23, 2017}} and the PC version has an average score of 88 from 30 critics.{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/night-in-the-woods | title = Night in the Woods for PC Reviews - Metacritic | work = [[Metacritic]] | accessdate = March 23, 2017}} Praise is mainly given to the writing and characters. In his review of both ''Night in the Woods'' and ''[[Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon Wildlands]]'', [[Ben "Yahtzee" Croshaw]] of ''[[Zero Punctuation]]'' said that ''Night in the Woods'' somewhat reminded him of ''[[Gone Home]]'', "'cos it eschews core gameplay in favor of storytelling; it takes a while to figure out what it's going for, and the supernatural horror stuff feels a bit at odds with the rest of the overall tone, but I respect the game for drawing a line under itself design-wise and not getting bogged down shoving in standard gameplay bullshit until it ultimately forgets to add anything new and the bullshit is all there is."{{cite web |last=Croshaw |first=Ben |date=March 29, 2017 |url=https://www.escapistmagazine.com/videos/view/zero-punctuation/117021-Tom-Clancy-Ghost-Recon-Wildlands-Review |title=Zero Punctuation: ''Ghost Recon Wildlands'' |publisher=''[[The Escapist (magazine)|The Escapist]]'' |accessdate=October 13, 2018}} ''[[Eurogamer]]'' ranked the game 13th on their list of the "Top 50 Games of 2017",{{cite web |author=Eurogamer staff |date=December 29, 2017 |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-12-29-eurogamers-top-50-games-of-2017-20-11 |title=Eurogamer's Top 50 Games of 2017: 20-11 |publisher=''[[Eurogamer]]'' |accessdate=December 31, 2017}} and ''[[GamesRadar+]]'' ranked it 17th on their list of the 25 Best Games of 2017,{{cite web |author=GamesRadar staff |date=December 22, 2017 |url=https://www.gamesradar.com/best-games-2017/ |title=The best games of 2017 |publisher=[[GamesRadar+]] |accessdate=March 25, 2018}} while ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' ranked it 23rd on their list of the 50 best games of 2017.{{cite web |author=Polygon staff |date=December 18, 2017 |url=https://www.polygon.com/2017-best-games/2017/12/18/16781674/best-video-games-2017-top-50-mario-pubg-zelda |title=The 50 best games of 2017 |publisher=''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' |accessdate=February 12, 2018}} The game was nominated for "Best Comedy Game" in ''[[PC Gamer]]''{{'}}s 2017 Game of the Year Awards.{{cite web |author=PC Gamer staff |date=December 8, 2017 |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/nominees-pc-gamer-goty-2017/ |title=Games of the Year 2017: The nominees |publisher=''[[PC Gamer]]'' |accessdate=January 1, 2018}} It won the award for "Best Adventure Game" in [[IGN]]'s Best of 2017 Awards,{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/wikis/best-of-2017-awards/Best_Adventure_Game|title=Best of 2017 Awards: Best Adventure Game|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=December 23, 2017}} whereas its other nominations were for "Best Art Direction", "Best Story", and "Best Original Music".{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/wikis/best-of-2017-awards/Best_Art_Direction|title=Best of 2017 Awards: Best Art Direction|publisher=IGN|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=December 23, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/wikis/best-of-2017-awards/Best_Story|title=Best of 2017 Awards: Best Story|publisher=IGN|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=December 23, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/wikis/best-of-2017-awards/Best_Original_Music|title=Best of 2017 Awards: Best Original Music|publisher=IGN|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate=December 23, 2017}} In [[Giant Bomb]]'s 2017 Game of the Year Awards, the game won the award for "Best Cast of Characters", and was a runner-up each for "Best Debut", "Best Story", and "Game of the Year".{{cite web |author=Giant Bomb staff |date=December 28, 2017 |url=https://www.giantbomb.com/articles/game-of-the-year-2017-day-four-debut-new-character/1100-5707/ |title=Game of the Year 2017 Day Four: Debut, New Characters, Story, and Styyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyle |publisher=[[Giant Bomb]] |accessdate=December 28, 2017}}{{cite web |author=Giant Bomb staff |date=December 29, 2017 |url=https://www.giantbomb.com/articles/game-of-the-year-2017-day-five-best-worst-cast-and/1100-5708/ |title=Game of the Year 2017 Day Five: Best, Worst, Cast, and Capture |publisher=Giant Bomb |accessdate=December 29, 2017}} It also won the award for "Best Character" (Mae) and "Best Dialogue" in ''[[Game Informer]]''{{'}}s 2017 Adventure Game of the Year Awards.{{cite web|url=http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2018/01/09/the-2017-adventure-game-of-the-year-awards.aspx|title=The 2017 Adventure Game Of The Year Awards|last=Favis|first=Elise|date=January 9, 2018|publisher=''Game Informer''|accessdate=January 9, 2018}} Before that, the game won the award "Best 2D Visuals" and the overall award "Golden Cube" in the [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] Awards 2017, whereas it was nominated for "Best Desktop/Console Game".{{cite web|url=https://awards.unity.com|title=Awards - Unity Awards 2017|publisher=[[Unity (game engine)|Unity]]|accessdate=October 4, 2017}} ===Awards=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Award !! Category !! Result !! Ref |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="7" | 2017 | rowspan="1" | [[SXSW Gaming Awards|SXSW Gamer's Voice Awards]] 2017 | Gamer's Voice (Single Player) | {{nom}} | rowspan="1" style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web |last=Aviles |first=Estevan |date=January 31, 2017 |url=https://gaming.sxsw.com/news/2017/gamers-voice-nominees-revealed-sxsw-gaming-2017/ |title=Gamer's Voice Nominees Revealed for SXSW Gaming 2017|publisher=[[South by Southwest|SXSW]]|accessdate=February 20, 2018}} |- | rowspan="4" | [[Golden Joystick Awards]] | Best Storytelling | {{nom}} | rowspan="4" style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web |last=Gaito |first=Eri |date=November 13, 2017 |url=https://www.bestinslot.co/golden-joystick-awards-2017-nominees/ |title=Golden Joystick Awards 2017 Nominees |publisher=Best in Slot |accessdate=December 23, 2017}}{{cite web |last=Weber |first=Rachel |date=November 17, 2017 |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/the-legend-of-zelda-breath-of-the-wild-scores-big-at-the-35th-golden-joystick-awards-presented-with-omen-by-hp/ |title=The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild scores big at the 35th Golden Joystick Awards presented with OMEN by HP |publisher=GamesRadar |accessdate=December 23, 2017}} |- | Best Visual Design | {{nom}} |- | Best Indie Game | {{nom}} |- | Breakthrough Award (Infinite Fall) | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2" | [[The Game Awards 2017]] | Games for Impact | {{nom}} | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-game-awards-2017-winners-headlined-by-zelda-br/1100-6455467/|title=The Game Awards 2017 Winners Headlined By Zelda: Breath Of The Wild's Game Of The Year|last=Makuch|first=Eddie|date=December 8, 2017|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=December 23, 2017}} |- | Best Independent Game | {{nom}} |- | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="19" | 2018 | rowspan="2" | 21st Annual [[D.I.C.E. Awards]] | Outstanding Achievement in Story | {{nom}} | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | {{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/game-of-the-year-nominees-announced-for-dice-award/1100-6456107/|title=Game Of The Year Nominees Announced for DICE Awards|last=Makuch|first=Eddie|date=January 14, 2018|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=January 18, 2018}} |- | D.I.C.E. Sprite Award | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="2" | [[National Academy of Video Game Trade Reviewers]] Awards | Art Direction, Contemporary | {{nom}} | rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;" | {{cite revision.text:
[[File:Ping Pong Show.JPG|right|300px|thumb|Neon sign outside the Super Pussy bar in [[Patpong]] district in Bangkok, which features a ping pong show.|alt=refer to caption]]
A '''ping pong show''' is a form of stage entertainment that takes place in [[strip club]]s. It is a type of [[sex show]] in which women use their [[Pubococcygeus|pelvic muscles]] to either hold, eject, or blow objects from their [[vagina|vaginal cavity]]. [[Ping pong#Ball|Ping pong balls]] are the most iconic objects used. The show has been popular in [[Southeast Asia]] (particularly [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]]) for several decades, and is primarily performed for foreign tourists. The show is in many cases associated with [[sex tourism]] and [[human rights]] concerns have been raised regarding the performers.
==Description== The show typically takes place on a stage or dance platform and often involves a single performer. Usually she performs while lying on her back, although some variations involve a standing performer.<ref name=Steinfatt/> The performer is commonly dressed in only a [[bikini]] top or [[bra]] and has her [[pubic hair]] shaved. Items can be inserted into the vagina either on stage as part of the performance or beforehand in preparation. As an alternative to ejecting the items using the pelvic muscles, objects are sometimes pulled out by hand.{{sfn|Sanders-McDonagh|2016|p=9}} The earliest versions of the show involved ping pong balls, but other diverse objects have since been used in the performance. They include eggs, bananas, long strings or ribbons, whistles, horns, pens, cigarettes, candles, darts, spinning tops, bottles, firecrackers, razor blades, and chopsticks. Another activity is the shooting of [[goldfish]] into a bowl, or stuffing a large frog inside to see how long she can keep it in. A male member of the audience may be brought onto the dance platform to hold a balloon while a dart is shot at it, or the performer may do a shoot around the table at balloons tied to each customer's chair.<ref name="price">{{cite web |url=http://pulitzercenter.org/blog/untold-stories/price-sexual-torture-usd-181month |title=The Price of Sexual Torture? US$181/month |date=2009-08-18 |last=Guzder |first=Deena |work=Thailand: Sex Tourism, Exploited Women |publisher=[[Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Blame It On Bangkok|author=J. F. Gump|publisher=Booksmango|year=2012|ISBN=9786162221378|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=usgM2LGBJ8YC|page=161}}</ref> Another example of audience participation involves the performer filling her vagina with beer, expelling it into a glass and inviting an audience member to drink it.{{sfn|Sanders-McDonagh|2016|p=9}}
==In Thailand== The popularity of ping pong shows in Thailand dates back to the early 1980s and a show is featured in the 1976 [[sexploitation film]] ''[[Emanuelle in Bangkok]]''.<ref name=Steinfatt/> The shows are officially prohibited under the [[Obscenity|obscenity legislation]] of [[Law of Thailand|Thai law]], and in 2004 the government further limited what is permitted.<ref>{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Prostitution and Sex Work: A-N. Vol. 1|author=Melissa Hope Ditmore|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=2006|ISBN=9780313329685|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=fcYq72qYRTcC|page=57}}</ref> Nevertheless, demand from foreign tourists and local police corruption usually results in the practice being implicitly condoned by Thai officials.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jake Scobey-Thal|title=Thai Police are Shocked, Shocked after Rihanna Exposes their Country's Sex Shows|url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2013/10/14/thailand_police_ping_pong_sex_show_rihanna_twitter|work=Foreign Policy|date=14 Oct 2013|accessdate=19 Sep 2014}}</ref> There are instances of women performing at ping pong shows also working as prostitutes,<ref name="price"/> but in many ping pong show bars performers do not sell sex to customers.{{sfn|Sanders-McDonagh|2016|p=9}} Although [[prostitution in Thailand]] is not strictly illegal, publicly soliciting and creating a nuisance is.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ilo-phuket.com/legal-documents/prostitution.html |title=Thailand Prostitution Laws: Prevention And Suppression Of Prostitution Act B.E. 2539 (1996) |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=ilo-phuket.com |publisher=International Law Office, Phuket |access-date=26 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=IES>{{cite book|editor1-last=Francoeur|editor1-first=Robert T.|title=The International Encyclopedia of Sexuality: Thailand|date=1997|publisher=The Continuum Publishing Company|location=New York| url=http://www.sexarchive.info/IES/thailand.html|accessdate=24 Feb 2015}}</ref>
Locations like [[Patpong]] in Bangkok, [[Walking Street, Pattaya]], Bangla Road in [[Phuket]] and Ta Pae Gate in [[Chiang Mai]] have numerous venues hosting ping-pong shows.{{sfn|Sanders-McDonagh|2016|p=9}} Customers are brought in by employees working for the ping-pong shows. They approach tourists and passers-by in streets such as Bangkok's [[Khaosan Road]] during the late evening and ask them if they want to see a show.<ref>{{cite book|title=Norn Lup? - A Journey of Railways, Roads and Wats|author=Rachel Beswetherick|publisher=Lulu.com|year=2013|ISBN=9781291324259|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=UNCjBAAAQBAJ|page=22}}</ref> They are frequently shown pictures of the show in a booklet.<ref>{{cite book|title=Miss Bangkok: Memoirs of a Thai Prostitute|author=Bua Boonmee|publisher=Maverick House|year=2015|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tkIYBgAAQBAJ}}</ref> The shows take place on the upper floors of bars and strip clubs in locations such as Bangkok's entertainment district [[Patpong]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Bangkok Encounter|author1=Austin Bush|author2=China Williams|publisher=Lonely Planet|year=2009|ISBN=9781742205120|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=AFwPgdKD6FEC|page=167}}</ref> while bikini-clad women dance in the ground floor bars.<ref>{{cite book|title=Bangkok Boy: The story of a stolen childhood|author=Chai Pinit|publisher=Maverick House|year=2015|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9BkYBgAAQBAJ}}</ref> An entry fee is usually charged, often equivalent to around {{Currency|10|US}}, though typically nearer {{Currency|20|US}} in Bangkok.{{sfn|Sanders-McDonagh|2016|p=9}} In some cases, instead of a [[cover charge]], the drinks are priced 3–4 times higher than usual and a purchase is required.<ref>{{cite book|title=Bangkok for Shy Guys: No-nonsense Travel Guide for Shy Independent Male Travelers| publisher=Central Information Services LLC|year=2006|ISBN=9780978994303|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Bn1a50rqhZsC|page=151}}</ref> Other possible charges can include show fees and exit charges. In addition, performers often go around asking for tips after they have finished their acts.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to survive a Bangkok ping pong show without getting horribly scammed|url=http://www.demflyers.com/2016/01/18/how-to-survive-a-bangkok-ping-pong-show-without-getting-horribly-scammed/|date=18 January 2016|author=Michael|website=DEM Flyers}}</ref>
==In Laos== The [[Laos|Laotian]] capital [[Vientiane]] was once famous for its brothels and ''ping-pong-show'' bars during the 1960s and 1970s as a result of the country's involvement in the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name=FandD>{{cite web |url=http://factsanddetails.com/southeast-asia/Laos/sub5_3b/entry-2961.html |title=Sex in Laos |author=Jeffrey Hays |date=2008 |website=Facts and Details |publisher= |access-date=21 September 2015 |quote=}}</ref> Travel writer [[Paul Theroux]] described a bar in 1973 Vientiane thus: “Your eyes get accustomed to the dark and you see the waitress is naked. Without warning she jumps on the chair, pokes a cigarette into her vagina and lights it, puffing it by contracting her uterine lungs."<ref>{{cite book |last= Theroux |first= Paul |date=1975 |title=The Great Railway Bazaar |url= |location= |publisher=Houghton Mifflin |page= |isbn=978-0141189147}}</ref> British journalist [[Christopher Robbins]] wrote that ''The White Rose'', a famous Vientiane bar during the war, featured floor shows in which women used their vaginas to smoke cigarettes and fling ping pong balls.<ref>{{cite book |last= Robbins |first= Christopher |date=1978 |title=Air America |url= |location= |publisher= |page= |isbn=978-1908059017}}</ref> Such shows have since disappeared and brothels are now prohibited by Laotian law.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.retire-asia.com/laovientiane.shtml |title=Vientiane, Laos 2015 – City Nightlife, Clubs, Sex and Lao Family Life |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website=www.retire-asia.com |publisher=Retire Asia |access-date=21 September 2015 |quote=}}</ref>
==In Europe== In the [[red light district]] of [[De Wallen]] in [[Amsterdam]] the ''Moulin Rouge'' and ''Casa Rosso'' theatres feature on-stage sex shows including variations on the ping pong show.{{sfn|Sanders-McDonagh|2016|p=10}}
==Human rights concerns== The ping pong show is designed to get people talking about it so that people will come to the bar to see it. Often customers come only to see the show and leave when it is over. This is good business for the bar, which makes much of its profits from drinks. However, the majority of the bar workers do not participate in the show. Research published in 2002 indicated that most bar workers regard the show as bad for business and do not like it. Many bar workers consider the show to be low-class and in bad taste, boring as it is the same every night, and liable to take attention away from the bar workers by focussing on the acts.<ref name=Steinfatt/>
An article in 2009 described an example of the working conditions of women at ping pong shows. The employees arrived at 18:00 and left at daybreak. They stamped a time card and were penalized 5 baht (US$0.14) for every minute they were late. Each month, they received two nights of leave and, if they did not miss any additional nights, they earned a salary of 6,000 baht (US$181), supplemented by tips.<ref name="price"/> In 2015 the average monthly income in Thailand was $489, according to the [[International Labour Organization]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Siam Voices |date= |title=Thailand’s trans sex workers seek empowerment, not pity |url=http://asiancorrespondent.com/2015/11/thailands-transsexual-workers-seek-empowerment-not-pity/ |newspaper=Asian Correspondent |location= |access-date=4 December 2015 }}</ref>
Some human rights organizations (such as [[Not for Sale (organization)|Not For Sale]]) have denounced ping pong shows as inherently misogynistic. [[Taina Bien-Aimé]] of [[Equality Now]] commented that: "The attitude that [sex work in places like ping pong shows] is empowering gives a green light to traffickers. We're trying to fight the commercial sex trade, not empower the sex trade."<ref name="economics">{{cite web |url=http://pulitzercenter.org/blog/untold-stories/economics-commercial-sexual-exploitation |title=The Economics of Commercial Sexual Exploitation |date=2009-08-25 |last=Guzder |first=Deena |work=Thailand: Sex Tourism, Exploited Women |publisher=[[Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting]] }}</ref> Some of the performers in ping pong shows in Thailand come from poorer neighbouring countries such as Myanmar, Cambodia, or Laos.<ref name="price"/> The closure of factories in Thailand during the [[Great Recession]] in the late 2000s led to an increase in unemployment in the country. Some women formerly engaged in factory work moved to Thailand's [[red-light district]]s and ended up working in ping pong shows. Bien-Aime commented: "Working 14 hours [a day] in a factory or blowing ping pong balls out of your vagina should not be a person's only choices in life."<ref name="economics" /> Although no pain or suffering is generally experienced by female performers during the show,<ref name=Steinfatt>{{cite book|pages=41–45|title=Working at the Bar: Sex Work and Health Communication in Thailand|author=Thomas M. Steinfatt|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|year=2002|ISBN=9781567505672|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=RG1TWe88ISMC}}</ref> there have been rare accidents in which performers have been seriously and irreparably injured.<ref name="price"/> The inclusion of a ping pong show scene in the film ''[[The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert#Racism and sexism controversy|The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert]]'' led to the film being criticised on the grounds of sexism and racism.
==See also== * [[Prostitution in Laos]] * [[Donkey show]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Leon, Harmon. [https://web.archive.org/web/20130925083417/http://www.nthword.com/issue2/ping_pong.php "Life is Like a Ping-Pong Ball in a Bangkok Strip Club"]. [[nthWORD]], Issue 2 (Spring/Summer 2009), pp. 29–36, [https://web.archive.org/web/20130925083417/http://www.nthword.com/issue2/ping_pong.php archived] at the [[Wayback Machine]], 25 Sep 2009. * {{cite web |url=http://lukeollett.com/blog/2009/06/19/ping-pong-show-in-bangkok-thailand |title=Impartial account of a ping pong show |first1= Luke |last1= Ollett |date=19 Jun 2009 |website=Our Thursday |publisher= |accessdate=6 Jan 2014}} * {{cite web |url=http://www.guyswhotravel.com/entry/superpussy-our-night-at-a-ping-pong-ball-show-in-bangkok |title=Super Pussy - Our Night At A Ping Pong Ball Show In Bangkok |author=Brad |date=7 Mar 2013 |website=Guys Who Travel |publisher= |accessdate=6 Jan 2014}} * {{cite book|title=Women and Sex Tourism Landscapes|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QiUlDwAAQBAJ|first=Erin|last=Sanders-McDonagh|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=2016|isbn=9781317601159|ref=harv}}

revision.text:
'''Prostitution in Egypt''' is illegal.<ref>{{cite web |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070714201301/http://www.interpol.int/Public/Children/SexualAbuse/NationalLaws/csaEgypt.pdf |archive-date=14 July 2007 |title=Legislation of Interpol member states on sexual offences against children - Egypt |url=http://www.interpol.int/Public/Children/SexualAbuse/NationalLaws/csaEgypt.pdf|website=Interpol|accessdate=2 April 2018|date= 2006}}</ref> The [[Egyptian National Police]] officially combats prostitution but, like almost all other countries, prostitution exists in Egypt. [[UNAIDS]] estimate there to be 23,000 prostitutes in the country,<ref>{{cite web |title=Sex workers: Population size estimate - Number, 2016 |url=http://www.aidsinfoonline.org/gam/stock/shared/dv/PivotData_2018_7_22_636678151733621264.htm |website=www.aidsinfoonline.org |publisher=UNAIDS |accessdate=21 July 2018}}</ref> including [[Egyptians]], [[Eastern Europe]]ans, and of many other nationalities.<ref name=alahram>{{cite newspaper|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080317024659/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/537/chrncls.htm|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2001/537/chrncls.htm|title=A Diwan of contemporary life|author=Dr Yunan Labib Rizk|newspaper=Al-Ahram Weekly|date=7–13 June 2001|archive-date=17 March 2008}}</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/2070639.stm "Egypt deports 'east European prostitutes'"] BBC News, 27 June 2002</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422014338/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/833/eg5.htm|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2007/833/eg5.htm|title=Devil in the detail|author=Shaden Shehab|newspaper=Al-Ahram Weekly|date=22–28 February 2007|archive-date=22 April 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.americanchronicle.com/articles/28109 "The Virgin Prostitute!"] by Marwa Rakha, ''American Chronicle'', 29 May 2007</ref>
== History== ===Ancient Egypt=== Prostitutes in Ancient Egypt were respected and even considered sacred as the first institutions where prostitution flourished were the temples of the Gods.<ref name="unesco">{{cite web | url = http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0006/000661/066103eb.pdf | title = Prostitution in Egypt | last = El Saadawi | first = Narwal | date = 1985 | website = | publisher = UNESCO | access-date = April 22, 2017 | quote = }}</ref> The god [[Amun]] indulged in sexual activity with many women under a religious guise. Families often gave their most beautiful daughters to the priests of his temple. As soon as they grew too old for the tastes of the priests they were allowed to leave. Many practised prostitution until they were married.<ref name="unesco" />
Some of the prostitutes wore blue [[faïence]]-beaded fishnet dresses, had red-painted lips and tattoos on their breasts or thighs.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.thekeep.org/~kunoichi/kunoichi/themestream/sexuality.html | title = Ancient Egyptian Sexuality: Life in Ancient Egypt | last = Seawright | first = Caroline | date = April 9, 2001 | website = | publisher = The Keep | access-date = April 22, 2017 | quote = }}</ref>
===Roman occupation=== As in the rest of the Roman Empire, prostitution was regulated. Prostitutes had to be registered<ref>Edwards, "Unspeakable Professions," p. 81.</ref> and taxes were collected from them.<ref>{{cite book |last= McGinn |first=Thomas A. J. |authorlink= |date= |title=Prostitution, Sexuality, and the Law in Ancient Rome |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BmH31IK-OgEC |publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2003|isbn=9780195161328}}</ref>
===Middle Ages=== Prostitution was generally tolerated and taxed during this period,<ref name="Gadelrab">{{cite book |last=Gadelrab |first=Sherry Sayed |authorlink= |year=2016 |title=Medicine and Morality in Egypt: Gender and Sexuality in the Nineteenth and Early Twentieth Centuries |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xT5MDAAAQBAJ |publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857737724}}</ref> the rulers taking the view that prohibition would not stop prostitution and that tax revenue would be lost.<ref name="Gadelrab" />
There were periods when prostitution was prohibited following pressure on the rulers from Muslim clerics.<ref name="Gadelrab" />
===Ottoman rule=== Under Ottoman rule, the regulation and taxation of prostitutes continued.<ref name="semerdjian">{{cite book |last=Semerdjian |first=Elyse |authorlink= |date= |title="Off the Straight Path": Illicit Sex, Law, and Community in Ottoman Aleppo |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZEAEnGz7CLAC |publisher=Syracuse University Press|year=2008|isbn=9780815631736}}</ref> During the 17th century two guilds for prostitutes were set up.<ref name="semerdjian" />
===French occupation=== Prostitution flourished following the [[French invasion of Egypt]] in 1798. The French organised additional prostitutes brought over from Europe.<ref name="unesco" /> [[Sexually transmitted infection|STI]]s spread rapidly through the brothels and this prompted the French authorities to introduce a law forbidding French troops from entering a brothel or having prostitutes in their rooms. Offenders received a death penalty.<ref name="unesco" />
===Rule of Muhammad Ali=== In 1834 [[Muhammad Ali Pasha]] outlawed prostitution<ref>{{cite book |last=Ditmore |first=Melissa Hope |date= |title=Encyclopedia of Prostitution and Sex Work: A-N. Vol. 1 |url= |location= |publisher= |page= |isbn= |author-link= }}</ref> and female public dancing in Cairo. The prostitutes and dancers were sent to [[Upper Egypt]], especially [[Qena|Kena]], [[Esna]] and [[Aswan]].<ref>{{cite web |title=The Dancer Of Esna |url=http://williamhpeck.org/the_dancer_of_esna |website=williamhpeck.org |accessdate=12 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref> In 1837 he extended this to all of Egypt.<ref name="semerdjian" />
Article 240 of the Mixed Penal Code of 1867 states: ''A pimp who incites young men or women below the age of 21 to evil practices leading to rape is to be punished by a period of imprisonment not less than one month and not more than one year''.<ref name="unesco" /> Article 241 increases the penalty if the offence is committed by the father, mother or guardian of a minor.<ref name="unesco" />
Following the abolition of slavery in 1877, many recently freed female slaves turned to prostitution to survive.<ref name="Gadelrab" />
===British occupation=== [[File:Prostitute license 1885.jpg|220px|thumb|1885 prostitute license issued in the Cairo municipality]] After the British occupation of 1882, the authorities were concerned about disease spreading amongst the troops. They made legal provisions to control prostitution and introduced a system of healthcare.<ref name="unesco" /><ref name="Gadelrab" /> In July 1885 Egypt's Ministry of the Interior introduced regulations for the health inspection of prostitutes.<ref name="unesco" /> Further regulations were introduced in 1896 to control brothels.<ref name="unesco" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Bearman |first=Peri |last2=Weiss |first2=Bernard G. |author-link2= |last3=Heinrichs |first3=Wolfhart |author-link3= |year=2008 |title= The Law Applied: Contextualizing the Islamic Shari'a |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OPEBAwAAQBAJ |location= |publisher=I. B. Tauris & Company |page= |isbn=9780857714275 |author-link= }}</ref>
Australian soldiers stationed in Egypt in [[World War I]] including the famous half Chinese Australian sniper [[Billy Sing#Western Front|Billy Sing]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Hamilton|first=John |year=2015|title= Gallipoli Sniper: The Remarkable Life of Billy Sing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ekeuCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA2#v=onepage&q&f=false|location= |publisher=Frontline Books|edition=illustrated |page=2 |isbn=978-1848329041|author-link= }}</ref> were major customers of Egyptian prostitutes in the local red light districts and brothels. High prices by the prostitutes led to the Wasser red light area becoming the scene of a major riot by New Zealand and Australian soldiers on Good Friday in 1915.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hamilton|first=John |year=2015|title= Gallipoli Sniper: The Remarkable Life of Billy Sing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ekeuCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA89#v=onepage&q&f=false|location= |publisher=Frontline Books|edition=illustrated |page=89 |isbn=978-1848329041|author-link= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Robinson |first=Russell |editor-last=Lyons |editor-first= Jo |year= 2014 |title= Khaki Crims and Desperadoes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bD2SAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT50#v=onepage&q&f=false|location= |publisher= Macmillan Publishers Aus. |edition=illustrated |page= |isbn= 978-1743518175 |author-link= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last= |first=|editor1-last= Damousi |editor1-first= Joy |editor2-last= Lake |editor2-first= Marilyn |year= 1995 |title= Gender and War: Australians at War in the Twentieth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fgk4AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA52#v=onepage&q&f=false|location= |publisher=CUP Archive|edition=illustrated|issue=Issue 16 of Studies in Australian History|page= 52|isbn=978-0521457101 |author-link= }}</ref> The Australian military arranged for medical treament for venereal diseaes among its soldiers in Port Said and Cairo.<ref>{{cite book |last= Featherstone |first=Lisa |year= 2011 |title= Let's Talk About Sex: Histories of Sexuality in Australia from Federation to the Pill|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VfsqBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA110#v=onepage&q&f=false|location= |publisher= Cambridge Scholars Publishing |page= 110|isbn= 978-1443828130 |author-link= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |author=Australian Medical Association, British Medical Association |year= 1915 |title= Medical Journal of Australia, Band 2|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6LU1AQAAMAAJ&q=erosions+commonest+appearance+australian+cairo|location= |publisher=Australasian Medical Publishing Company|page= 485|isbn= |author-link= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |author= |year= 1962 |title=Australia in the War of 1939-1945 : Ser. 5. Medical, Band 1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZFQhAQAAIAAJ&q=cases+seen+respiratory+serum+australian+cairo&dq=cases+seen+respiratory+serum+australian+cairo|location= |publisher=Australian War Memorial|page= 235|isbn= |author-link= }}</ref>
In 1932 a Cabinet decree abolished licences for prostitution and established the 'Public Morals Police'.<ref name="unesco" />
A new penal code was introduced in 1937 and included a section to punish men who lived off the earnings of prostitutes.<ref name="unesco" />
In 1949 Military Order no. 76 was issued abolishing brothels.<ref name="unesco" />
Law No. 68, introduced in 1951, penalizing:<ref name="unesco" /> * Acts of prostitution if carried out habitually * Acts of prostitution whether carried out by males or females (The term 'prostitution' was used in regard to females, For males the term used was 'licentiousness') * Acts inciting others to engage in prostitution * International trading of prostitutes ([[white slave trade]]) * The provision of housing or other premises where prostitutes can carry on their trade * The advertisement of prostitution whether in an open or disguised way.
== The prostitution system == The prostitution system in Egypt often depends on [[pimp]]ing, although women also work alone. Pimps in Egypt organize the work of a group of prostitutes and receive a percentage of their profits. This is called the network in Egypt. This system is mainly used in [[Cairo]] and [[Alexandria]] and other big cities.{{Citation needed|date=August 2017}}
==Nikah mut‘ah== [[Nikah mut‘ah]] is a temporary marriage allowed under Shia Islam Law. The 'marriage' may last for a term of one hour to one year. It is sometimes used to circumvent the prostitution laws.<ref name="zocalo">{{cite web | url = http://www.zocalopublicsquare.org/2010/10/24/what-we-dont-know-about-sex-in-the-middle-east/ideas/up-for-discussion/ | title = What We Don't Know about Sex in the Middle East | last = | first = | date = | website = | publisher = Zocalo | access-date = April 22, 2017 | quote = }}</ref>
===Summer marriages=== Wealthy men from the Gulf states often holiday in Egypt in the summer months. Whilst there they may take a young, temporary bride (often under-age) in a so-called ''summer marriage''. The marriages are arranged through a marriage broker and the girl's parents receive gifts and money as a 'dowry'. The marriage ends when the men return to their own country.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/scandal-of-summer-brides-7944467.html | title = Scandal of 'summer brides' | last = Milena | first = Veselinovic | date = July 14, 2012 | website = | publisher = The Independent | access-date = April 22, 2017 | quote = }}</ref>
== Prostitution in the economy == As prostitution is illegal in Egypt, no taxes are paid. The law exposes people who practice [[adultery]] to a jail sentence up to six months. For prostitution, the sentence is up to 3 years.<ref>{{cite web|title=100 Countries and Their Prostitution Policies|url=http://prostitution.procon.org/view.resource.php?resourceID=000772#egypt|website=ProCon.org|date=18 May 2016}}</ref>
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in Egypt}} Egypt is a source, transit, and destination country for women and children subjected to sex trafficking. Egyptian children are vulnerable to sex trafficking. Individuals from the Persian Gulf, including Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates, and Kuwait purchase Egyptian women and girls for "temporary" or "summer" marriages for the purpose of commercial sex, including cases of sex trafficking; these arrangements are often facilitated by the victims' parents and marriage brokers, who profit from the transaction. Child sex tourism occurs primarily in Cairo, Alexandria, and Luxor.<ref name="state18">{{cite web |title=Egypt 2018 Trafficking in Persons Report |url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2018/282648.htm |website=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=28 July 2018}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
Women and girls, including refugees and migrants, from Asia, Sub-Saharan Africa, and the Middle East endure sex trafficking in Egypt. Syrian refugees who have settled in Egypt remain increasingly vulnerable to exploitation, including sex trafficking, and transactional marriages of girls—which can lead to sexual exploitation, including sex trafficking,<ref name="state18" />
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Egypt as a '[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2]]' country.<ref name="state18" />

Wynn, ''American Sexuality'' magazine, 26 June 2008
